intro.para: When a force acts on an object, it does so in a certain direction and with a certain strength. Thus we can model a force by a vector. The direction in which the force acts corresponds to the direction of the vector, and the magnitude of the force corresponds to the length of the vector.

section.body.para:

info.caption: What does the red vector represent?
info.para: This vector represents a force of 4000N to the right.

info.caption: What does the green vector represent?
info.para: This vector represents a force of \sqrt{58} \cdot 1000N directed to the upper right.

info.caption: What does the blue vector represent?
info.para: This vector represents a force of 5000N directed to the lower right

section.body.para: From experiments we learn that several forces acting simultaneously on an object can be consolidated into a single force. Moreover, the consolidated force corresponds to the vector sum of the individual forces. â€“ The picture below illustrates this. Here we have two forces, F_1 and F_2 acting on an object. The resulting combined force is described by the red vector F_1 + F_2.

info.caption: What does the green vector represent?
info.para: This vector represents the force vector F_2 acting on the object, assumed to be at its tail.

info.caption: What does the blue vector represent?
info.para: This vector represents the force vector F_1 acting on the object, assumed to be at its tail.

info.caption: What does the red vector represent?
info.para: This vector represents the single force that results from the combined actions of F_1 and F_2.
